lessons.title: Learn the Board - Files
lessons.description: Files are the vertical columns on a chess board, labeled a-h from White's left to right.

content.explanation: Files are labeled with letters a-h from White's left to right. From Black's perspective, the files appear reversed (h-a).

practice.question: What file is this piece on?

lessons.title: Learn the Board - Ranks
lessons.description: Ranks are the horizontal rows on a chess board, numbered 1-8 from White's bottom to top.

content.explanation: Ranks are numbered 1-8 from bottom to top from White's perspective. From Black's perspective, the ranks appear reversed (8-1).

practice.question: What rank is this piece on?

lessons.title: Chess Piece Notation
lessons.description: Learn how each chess piece is represented in algebraic notation.

pieces.name: King
pieces.description: The king is represented by the letter K

pieces.name: Queen
pieces.description: The queen is represented by the letter Q

pieces.name: Rook
pieces.description: The rook is represented by the letter R

pieces.name: Bishop
pieces.description: The bishop is represented by the letter B

pieces.name: Knight
pieces.description: The knight is represented by the letter N (not K)

pieces.name: Pawn
pieces.description: Pawns don't use a letter - just the square they move to

lessons.title: Basic Moves
lessons.description: Learn how to write basic chess moves in algebraic notation.

lessons.title: Captures
lessons.description: When a piece captures another piece, we write the piece letter, then 'x', then the destination square.

practice.question: How would you write: "Queen captures on square f7"?

lessons.title: Pawn Captures
lessons.description: When a pawn captures another piece, we write the file it moves from, then 'x', then the destination square.

example.explanation: Pawn from e-file captures on d5

practice.question: How would you write: "Pawn from c-file captures on d4"?

lessons.title: Check
lessons.description: When a move puts the opponent's king in check, we add '+' at the end of the move.

example.explanation: Queen moves to e7, giving check

practice.question: How would you write: "Bishop moves to f6, giving check"?

lessons.title: Checkmate
lessons.description: When a move delivers checkmate, we add '#' at the end of the move.

example.explanation: Queen moves to h7, delivering checkmate

practice.question: How would you write: "Rook moves to e8, delivering checkmate"?
